journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Friction of a pimpled rugby ball surface: Force and velocity weakening and strengthening of the coefficient of friction

article-meta.aff: School of Aerospace, Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, RMIT University, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Franz K Fuss, School of Aerospace, Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, RMIT University, Bundoora Campus, Plenty Road, PO Box 71, Bundoora, Victoria 3083, Australia. Email: franz.fuss@rmit.edu.au

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Tribology of Sport

abstract.p: Friction of rubber is known to behave non-linearly, depending on contact pressure and sliding speed. The surface of a rugby ball made of natural rubber with regular pimples was investigated, and the coefficient of friction between finger skin and rubber surface was determined at normal forces of 0.4–40 N and sliding speeds of 0.001–3.2 m/s. The kinetic coefficient of friction asymptoted to the static coefficient at small speeds. The coefficient of friction exhibited force strengthening and weakening, as well as velocity strengthening and weakening. The maximal coefficient of friction amounted to 3.55 at a normal force of 1 N and a sliding speed of 70 mm/s. When throwing a ball, the coefficient of friction is static and in the force weakening regime at the beginning of the acceleration phase, then moves to the velocity strengthening regimes once finger sliding sets in and finally crosses over to the force strengthening and velocity weakening regimes before the fingers leave contact with the ball.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Velocity and force dependencies of the coefficient of friction (COF) are well-known phenomena. In the velocity strengthening regime, the COF increases with sliding speed; in the velocity weakening regime, the COF decreases with sliding speed; in the force strengthening regime, the COF increases with normal load; and in the force weakening regime, the COF decreases with normal load.
The following section gives a short overview of the mathematical models of the four different dependencies and regimes.

sec.title: Velocity strengthening and weakening
sec.p: Dieterich1 mathematically modelled for the first time the velocity weakening of rock friction, based on displacement dependency and time dependency. The model was improved by Ruina2 resulting in the Dieterich–Ruina or slowness law3 (1) where τ is the shear stress, σ the effective normal stress, v the slip velocity, v0 the reference velocity, μ0 the steady-state friction at v = v0, L the critical slip distance, θ the state variable, A and B the frictional material parameters (with A denoting the increase in μ on initial application of v as a direct velocity effect, and B the subsequent decrease in μ as an evolutionary effect) and log denotes the natural logarithm.3 Initial velocity strengthening occurs if A > B,3 followed by velocity weakening once A < B.2,3 Velocity weakening of experimental rock friction data follows a linear function of the kinetic COF μk against log v.2

Non-linear frictional behaviour is known from composites (velocity weakening4) and polymers such as polytetrafluoroethylene and polyethylene (velocity strengthening) and Nylon 6-6 (velocity weakening) at v < 10 mm/s and at room temperature.5

Rubber friction (e.g. on hard surfaces) exhibits velocity strengthening followed by weakening.6–8 According to Grosch,6,9 the friction of rubber can be described by its master curve (i.e. velocity strengthening and weakening) and by the glass transition temperature of the rubber. Grosch6 discovered that the ratio λ of the velocity v of maximal friction μkmax to the frequency f, at which the loss modulus E″ has its maximum, is constant (if compared at the same temperature) (2)
This indicates that the rubber friction is governed by the deformation losses of the material and thus by the visco-elastic properties of the rubber.

Bureau et al.10 suggested a logarithmic function for the velocity strengthening regime at sliding speeds smaller than 0.1 mm/s of a poly methyl methacrylate block sliding on soda lime glass. However, Bureau et al.11 generalise that velocity weakening applies to sliding speeds smaller than 0.1 mm/s.

sec.title: Force strengthening and weakening
sec.p: Load dependency was investigated by Schallamach12 and Lincoln13 who empirically, and mathematically via the Hertzian contact equation, found that the radius of the contact area is a cube root function, even if Hertzian contact is only applicable to small deformations. Based on this function (3) where c is a velocity-dependent constant12 and N the normal force. Thus (4) where F is the friction (shear) force and n the general power-law exponent. The exponent n equals 2/3 in perfect elastic deformation, and n equals 1 in plastic deformation. In reality, 0.667 < n < 1.14,15 The exponent n data of viscose rayon determined by Guthrie and Oliver16 fit into this range. The exponent n for diamond was reported at 0.8.14 Howell and Mazur15 determined n for drawn nylon at 0.8 (c = 0.92), for undrawn nylon at 0.9 (c = 0.85), for viscose rayon at 0.91 (c = 0.49) and for cellulose acetate at 0.96 (c = 0.6).
No function or model of the force strengthening regime was found in literature.

sec.title: Master surface including all four regimes
sec.p: To the best of the author’s knowledge, the only master surface showing all four regimes in a single surface was provided by Lindner et al.,8 investigating the friction between a rubber compound and a wet road surface. They determined the COF over a speed range of 5–500 mm/s and over a force range of 60–120 N.

Tomlinson17 investigated the friction between the human finger and different materials including rugby ball surfaces. Her results indicate force weakening in brass, nylon, PVC, HDPE and acetal, and force strengthening in polypropylene in the force range 2–10 N. Tomlinson17 did not measure the velocity dependency, and sliding speed ‘of the finger moving on the surface was controlled by asking the participants to count slowly to five from the start to the finish of the slide’. This resulted in speeds 8–20 mm/s in dry surface conditions. Although Tomlinson17 and Tomlinson et al.18 recorded the speed and spin of a thrown ball leaving the hand, they did not determine the actual relative sliding speed of the fingers with respect to the ball.

Friction in ball sports is directly connected to handling the ball, speed and precision of the game. The better the grip, the faster the game becomes, the more exciting it is for the spectators and the larger are the performance differences of elite players (in terms of reaction time, running speed, precision of catch and following team strategy and tactics) compared to lower speed. The precision of throwing was measured by Tomlinson17 and Tomlinson et al.,18 which correlated with the friction coefficients determined.

Rugby is played in two different forms: rugby league and rugby union football. The main differences between the two forms are that league football has fewer, clearer and simpler rules, and the game is faster with fewer interruptions, which makes it more interesting for spectators but also more athletically demanding for players. The number of players is different as well, with 13 in league football, and 15 in union football. The material of rugby balls is regulated by the laws of the game.

Rugby league:19 ‘ … oval air inflated ball, the outer casing of which shall be leather or other material approved by the International Board and nothing shall be used in its construction which might prove dangerous to the players’.
Rugby union:20 ‘Leather or suitable synthetic material. It may be treated to make it water resistant and easier to grip’.

The rugby union law specifically mentions the grip, whereas the rugby league does not refer to the surface properties of the ball. Standard rugby balls are made of rubber compound with a structured surface (pimples of different shapes and sizes).

The mass of the union ball is 410–460 g and its dimensions are: length 280–300 mm, end-to-end circumference 740–770 mm and width circumference 580–620 mm.20 The mass of the league ball is 380–440 g, and its dimensions are: length 270–290 mm, end-to-end circumference 730–750 mm, and width circumference 580–610 mm.19 Union balls are slightly less pointed than league ones.

The aim of this study is to explore and investigate the force and velocity dependence of the COF between finger and a rugby ball surface at variable normal loads and sliding speeds in order to understand the influence of load and speed on the grip. In particular, the aim was to map the COF on a large range (varying at least over a factor of 100), of sliding speeds and normal loads in order to provide a three-dimensional master surface of the COF and to discuss the applicability of this master surface to improving the grip when playing rugby.

sec.title: Ball surface
sec.p:
The surface tested was an experimental pimple design developed by Gray-Nicolls/Steeden. The surface was designed for rugby league balls. The ball material was identified as natural rubber with FT-Raman spectroscopy. The surface consisted of a regular pimple pattern (Figure 1) with pimple density 50.28%, diameter 1.19 mm and height 0.53 mm. All friction tests were conducted parallel to the pimple rows. Figure 1.
Pimple pattern of the surface tested; the arrows indicate the test direction; horizontal scale bar: 10 mm.

sec.title: Friction tests
sec.p:
The tests were carried out on a portable Kistler force plate (type 9260AA, Kistler, Winterthur, Switzerland; Figure 2). The measurement mode was set to the recording range with the highest sensitivity in the software (Bioware, Kistler, Winterthur, Switzerland), corresponding to 0.032 N for normal force and 0.016 N for shear force. The force plate was calibrated with defined masses and spring balances in the z- and y-directions (normal and horizontal directions, respectively). The centre of pressure (COP) was calibrated along the symmetry axis of the force plate (along the y-axis) in the mid-section of the force plate by applying forces of different magnitudes and angles with a ballpoint pen at 10 mm increments. The COP positions calculated by the software were compared to the actual location of the COP, and an error map was obtained which allowed correcting the COP locations provided by the software. Figure 2.
Experimental setup; 1 = rubber sheet, 2 = force plate, 3 = clamp, arrow = direction of finger motion.

The pimpled rubber sheet was clamped to the force plate and the vertical and horizontal forces data were recoded at 1 kHz. Both rubber sheet and finger skin were cleaned with alcohol before testing. For consistency purposes, only the right index finger of a single test person (male, 47 years) was used for testing. The finger was placed on the rubber sheet by increasing the normal force first, followed by a slow increase in friction force such that the finger started to slide very slowly at the point of impending slippage. Subsequently, the sliding speed was rapidly increased until reaching the maximally possible velocity. The tests were carried out at different initial normal forces in order to cover a wide force range. The influence of finger temperature (rising with sliding distance) was determined by sliding the finger at different constant speeds and loads by fitting the data with a linear regression equation and comparing the data shortly after beginning of the slide to the data shortly before the end of the slide. The difference in the COF was statistically not significant.

A total of 50 tests was performed, distributed over 10 days. The five tests per day covered the range from minimal to maximal load. It was impossible to keep the load constant per test, as the finger tended to press harder at faster sliding speeds. Only tests with steady sliding were processed and any test exhibiting stick–slip behaviour was discarded. All tests were randomly carried out in the same parallel directions distributed over the rubber sheet. After the tests, there was no sign of wear on the rubber sheet.

sec.title: Basic data processing
sec.p:
The COF was calculated from the ratio of friction to normal force. The initial data of each test were removed once the COF reached a maximum before the point of impending slippage, determined from the movement of the COP. The sliding speed was calculated from fitting the time series of COP data (Figure 3) with a higher order polynomial fit (Matlab R2008b, MathWorks, Natick, MA, USA) and calculating the first derivative from the fit equation. After completing data processing, the data were truncated to a force-velocity area ranging 0.4–40 N and 0.001–3.2 m/s. Figure 3.
Raw data, position of COP against time. COP: centre of pressure.

sec.title: Determination of non-linear properties
sec.p:
The raw data (Figure 4) of all 50 tests were combined in a single file (velocity, force and COF data) and sorted as to velocity or force. The data were analysed with different fit functions including the ones suggested in literature (e.g. logarithmic velocity weakening and power-law force weakening) for small velocity and force windows (e.g. 6–8 N in Figure 5, 0.4–0.6 m/s in Figure 6). Figure 4.
Raw data, COF against velocity; normal force between 0.77 and 1.28 N. COF: coefficient of friction. Figure 5.
COF against sliding velocity at normal forces of 6–8 N; grey curve: rational function fit according to equation (5); the arrow indicates where the kinetic COF asymptotes towards the static COF. COF: coefficient of friction. Figure 6.
COF against normal force at sliding velocities of 0.4–0.6 m/s; grey curves: data fit curves according to equations (6) and (7). COF: coefficient of friction.

The best fit of COF against velocity v (m/s) resulted from a rational function of the form (5) for specific force windows (Figure 5), where A1, B1, C1 and D1 are the coefficients of the function. The rational function covered both velocity strengthening and weakening segments. The fit curve corresponds to the kinetic COF, and its intercept to the static COF.

A single fit curve was not applicable to the COF against force F (N) due to the sharp transition between force strengthening and weakening segments, despite plotting them on a logarithmic force scale (Figure 6). For specific velocity windows, the COF was plotted against the decadic logarithm of the force, and the force strengthening segment was fit with an exponential function of the form (6) where A2 and B2 are the coefficients of the function. A linear function of COF against log10 F was not applicable, as this function could result in negative COF when extrapolating to small forces.

The force weakening segment was fit with a logarithmic function of the form (7) where A3 and B3 are the coefficients of the function and log and log10 the natural and decadic logarithms, respectively.

The velocity fit COF data determined for specific force windows were sorted according to magnitude of the force, and combined with the force fit COF data determined for specific velocity windows and vice versa. The combined new (filtered) data sets underwent the same fitting procedure as described above in order to produce converging data sets and a smooth master surface of COF against force and velocity. The entire processed data set was imported in AutoCAD 2002 (by Autodesk, San Rafael CA, USA) and displayed as a rendered surface on linear and logarithmic velocity and force axes.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The COF showed both force strengthening and weakening as well as both velocity strengthening and weakening. The transition from strengthening to weakening was represented by a peak sharper in the force dependency (on a logarithmic force scale; Figure 6) than in the velocity dependency (on a logarithmic velocity scale; Figure 5).

The peak COF, ranging between 3.5 and 3.6, was found at a normal force of 1 N and a sliding speed of 70 mm/s (Figures 7 to 9). The COF master surface is shown in Figures 7 and 8. Figure 7.
3D graph of COF against the decadic logarithm of velocity and normal force (COF master surface) at four different iso-views; the arrow indicates where the kinetic COF asymptotes towards the static COF. Figure 8.
3D graph of COF against velocity and normal force (COF master surface) at four different iso-views. COF: coefficient of friction. Figure 9.
Contour plot of the COF surface; the isotribes are displayed in increments of 0.2 with the maximum at 3.5 (3.5 < COF < 3.6, white central area); black rectangle: normal force and speed data range of Tomlinson et al.;18 the arrow points at the normal force and speed data of Fuss and Troynikov.21 COF: coefficient of friction.

The COF shows large fluctuations, especially at the force strengthening segment (Figure 6), stretching over a COF range of up to 1. On that part of the master surface, the slopes are rather steep and the wide range of raw COF data is partially due to width of the speed window used for fit functions.

Figure 9 shows the contour plot of COF master surface and displays the isotribes, i.e. lines of identical friction. The minimum COF within the contour plot amounts to 0.3 and is located at small normal force and high sliding speed.

sec.title: Non-linear behaviour of the COF
sec.p: The results clearly indicate that the COF undergoes both strengthening and weakening in terms of sliding velocity and normal force. In the rugby ball surface tested, μs was equal to the initial values of μk at very low velocities. Tyre rubber compounds behave in the same way at very low sliding velocities, i.e. μs ≈ μk.7 However, if the rubber compound consists of ‘a mixture of two different rubbers with very different glass transition temperatures’,7 then ‘there is no single value of the static friction coefficient—it depends upon the initial dwell time and rate of starting’.7

The peak μk occurred at 70 mm/s (F = 1 N); at smaller forces, the local peak μk approached 0.3 m/s. The peak μk found by Grosch6 in acrylonitrile butadiene rubber sliding on glass or silicon carbide was below 30 mm/s. Lindner et al.8 found the peak μk between a rubber compound and a wet road surface at a normal load of 90 N and a sliding speed of 50 mm/s. Tomlinson17 and Tomlinson et al.18 analysed their four rugby ball surfaces at normal loads of 12 ± 2.5 N and velocities of 14 ± 6 mm/s (Figure 9). Compared to the results of this study, the data of Tomlinson17 and Tomlinson et al.18 are located on the velocity strengthening side of the COF master surface (Figure 9), but also on the force weakening side. The mean COF of the four surfaces in dry conditions, obtained by Tomlinson17 and Tomlinson et al.,18 ranged 1.1–1.8. The COF obtained from this study fell between 1.5 and 1.7 within Tomlinson’s17 speed and normal force window (Figure 9).

Fuss and Troynikov21 investigated the directional friction of five different rugby ball surfaces with a KES_FB4 surface testing machine (Kato Tech Co. Ltd., Kyoto, Japan). The COF of the surface shown in Figure 1 was determined at 1.237 ± 0.119. The velocity and the average normal force of the KES_FB4 friction probe were 1 mm/s and 0.5 N. The average COF data between finger skin and the ball surface determined with the method described in the section ‘Experimental’ at 1 mm/s and 0.5 N fell between 1.1 and 1.3 (Figure 9). Although the KES_FB4 friction probe consists of 10 steel wires (diameter 0.5 mm) in series (total area: 25 mm2), the data obtained with both methods are in good agreement.

sec.title: Velocity strengthening and weakening
sec.p: According to the Dieterich–Ruina or slowness law3 of equation (1), the COF of the velocity weakening regime is a logarithmic function of the sliding speed. Bureau et al.10 suggested a logarithmic function for the velocity strengthening regime. This function seems to be applicable only locally, for sliding speeds smaller than 0.1 mm/s. However, the two regimes cannot be treated separately, as the transition from strengthening to weakening is rather smooth.6 In order to apply a fit function to both regimes including their transitions at the local peak COF, a rational function of equation (5) or a Bateman function of the form (8) are suitable. In both functions, the major part of the weakening shank is near-linear over a large range when plotting the function against the logarithm of speed. This indicates that the logarithmic function according to equation (1) is still valid locally.

sec.title: Force strengthening and weakening
sec.p: Ramalho et al.22 did not find any force weakening or strengthening effect in the COF of skin against glass (from 0 to ∼60 N at a speed of ∼40 mm/s). This indicates that the friction between glass and skin is independent of the contact area. Equations (3) and (4), however, hinge on the change of the contact area with normal force. Both Tomlinson’s results17 and own results described above demonstrate a non-linear COF behaviour as a function of the normal force. A power-law relationship according to equations (3) and (4) could neither be found by Tomlinson17 and Tomlinson et al.23 nor in the force weakening behaviour of the present results. Tomlinson et al.23 discussed possible reasons of the inapplicability of a power law. The main reason seems to be that the finger contact area does not continuously increase with normal force, but rather reaches a steady state at normal loads of 2–7 N,17 depending on the softness of the skin and subcutaneous fat. The deviation of the force weakening results from the traditional power law required to adopt a different empirical model according to equation (7). This equation also provides a near-perfect fit to Tomlinson’s17 force weakening results shown in her Figure 4.11.17

As there was no model function of the force strengthening regime available in literature, the fit function of equation (8) had to be found empirically, considering that the COF always has to be positive.

sec.title: Implications for the grip of rugby balls
sec.p: The term ‘grip’ can be defined by: the better the grip, the less easily does a ball slip off the player’s hands under the same conditions. This would naturally be achieved by maximising the friction force. There are two ways of how to increase the friction force: improving the COF and leave the normal force unchanged, or keeping the COF and increase the normal force. In the latter case, the conditions do change and would affect the movements of a player on the field. Thus, it is desired to maximise the COF. The highest COF (3.5) would result at a normal force of 1 N and a sliding speed of 70 mm/s (Figure 9). However, when throwing a ball, the fingers are still stationary and do not slide over the surface of the ball. Consequently, static conditions apply.

The mean and maximum ball speeds v and spin rates ω measured by Holmes et al.24 in elite rugby union players when passing a ball were 13.8 m/s, 18.3 m/s, 22.9 rad/s and 30.3 rad/s. The mean ball speeds and spin rates measured by Tomlinson et al.18 in volunteers were 10.7 m/s and 15.5 rad/s. Considering a ball of 0.435 kg mass m, 95.5 mm waist radius r (corresponding to a width circumference of 600 mm), an axial moment of inertia I of 0.00264 kgm2 (from 2mr2/3), a distance x of 0.8 m over which the ball is accelerated, an initial ball speed v of 0 m/s, linearly increasing ball speeds (v and ω) during acceleration, and thus constant linear (a) and angular (α) accelerations, then the times t required for accelerating the ball up to 13.8, 18.3 and 10.7 m/s are 0.116, 0.087 and 0.15 s (t = 2 x/v), and the linear (a) and angular (α) accelerations are 118.9, 209.3 and 71.6 m/s2; and 197.7, 344.9 and 103.6 rad/s2, respectively (Table 1). From the accelerations, the axial (FA, in throwing direction) and circumferential (FC, perpendicular to the ball axis) friction forces are calculated as follows (9) and (10) where T is the torque imparted onto the ball. Table 1.
Calculation of forces required to throw a ball.
Speed data Linear velocity, v, (m/s) Angular velocity, ω, (rad/s) Distance, x, (m) Time, t, (s) Linear acceleration, a, (m/s2) Angular acceleration, a, (rad/s2) Mass, m, (kg) Moment of inertia, I, (kg m2) Axial friction force, FA, (N) Circumferential friction force, FC, (N) Resultant friction force (N) per finger Static COFa Normal force (N)a
Holmes et al.,24 mean 13.8 22.9 0.8 0.116 118.9 197.7 0.435 0.00264 51.7 5.5 5.20 1.8 2.89
Holmes et al.,24 maximum 18.3 30.2 0.8 0.087 209.3 344.9 0.435 0.00264 91.0 6 9.15 1.65 5.55
Tomlinson et al.,18 mean 10.7 15.5 0.8 0.150 71.6 103.6 0.435 0.00264 31.1 2.9 3.13 2.2 1.42
COF: coefficient of friction. a
Static COF and normal forces match according to Figure 9.

If the friction forces are evenly distributed over 10 fingers, then the resultant forces of FA and FC at each finger required to reach the aforementioned speeds are 5.2, 9.15 and 3.13 N, respectively (Table 1). The corresponding static friction coefficients and normal forces are determined from Figure 9. The static COFs are around 1.8, 1.65 and 2.2, and the normal forces are 2.89, 5.55 and 1.42 N. These normal forces are the minimum requirement for preventing slippage and can well be higher. The magnitude of the normal forces indicates that at the beginning of a throw, the forces are in the force weakening regime. It is unclear when exactly the fingers start to slide. According to Tomlinson et al.,18 ‘in the process of providing spin to the ball, the fingers leave contact with the ball surface, one after another. Starting firstly with the thumb and finishing finally with the little finger’. From their Figure 8,18 it becomes clear that sliding of the fingers is initiated by flexing them consecutively, i.e. the middle finger remains stationary, whereas the index starts to slide and finally leaves contact with the ball. It is estimated that the entire sliding process lasts for about 15 ms from thumb to little finger (6 ms thereof shown in Figure 8 of Tomlinson et al.18). Considering that the time required for accelerating the ball is 0.15 s (Table 1; calculated from speed data by Tomlinson et al.18), sliding takes place approximately in the last 10% of the throwing action. At small sliding speeds, the COF is in the force weakening and velocity strengthening regimes. The maximal sliding speed of the fingers relative to the surface of the ball is unknown; however, it can be estimated as follows: from Figure 8 of Tomlinson et al.,18 the index finger seems to move by about 30 mm within 6 ms. The average speed would then be 5 m/s. The surface speed at the end of the acceleration phase is 1.5 m/s (ωr). The sliding speed of the finger then amounts to 3.5 m/s. Considering this average speed and the unloading of the fingers before leaving contact, the COF is located in the force strengthening and velocity weakening regimes of the COF master surface (Figure 9).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The friction coefficient between finger skin and pimpled rubber surface of a rugby ball is highly non-linear and exhibits force strengthening at smaller forces, force weakening at higher forces, velocity strengthening at slower speeds and velocity weakening at faster speeds.
The kinetic COF asymptotes to the static coefficient at small speeds.
The maximal COF amounts to 3.55 at a normal force of 1 N and a sliding speed of 70 mm/s.

When throwing a ball, the COF is static and in the force weakening regime at the beginning of the acceleration phase, then moves to the velocity strengthening regimes once finger sliding sets in and finally crosses over to the force strengthening and velocity weakening regimes before the fingers leave contact with the ball.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by Gray-Nicolls Sports Pty Ltd.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest.
